awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fostering Public Engagement in Computational Thinking by Leveraging Quilting Communities and Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches, and resources for use in a variety of settings. The pilot and feasibility study will develop instructional workshops for an adult population of quilters to introduce them to computational thinking. By leveraging pre-existing social structures, skill sets, and engagement in quilting, the researchers hope to help participants develop computer science and computational thinking knowledge and skills. The long-term goal is to broaden public awareness of computational thinking and build links between computer science and other areas of interest. By leveraging the social structure and existing skills held by practicing quilters, the workshops have the potential to reach an audience of millions of quilters around the nation and worldwide, the majority of whom are adult women.

The research will be developed and tested with two groups: the Orlando Modern Quilt Guild in Orlando, FL, and an informally gathered quilting class in the Worcester, MA area. Outcomes for the project include workshop materials that can be used in a variety of quilting group contexts nationwide, a deeper understanding of the processes and mechanisms for adult computer science education through crafts, and evaluation of the pilot workshop focused on the impact on participants' engagement, self-identity, and learning for computational thinking. The research especially focuses on leveraging pre-existing knowledge, interests, and social structures to draw connections to computational thinking, and studying how this impacts participants' self-described identity, attitude, and engagement with computer science. The project also assesses a novel method for teaching computational thinking that has potential for broad applicability in a variety of social and creative hobbies. Participants will use and modify generative design software that creates quilt designs and, in doing so, learn how creative interests can be expanded through computer science. By focusing on the hobby of quilting, which is not typically associated with computer science, the knowledge built through designing and evaluating the research offers strategies for altering public perception of computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the Code Crafters project, we investigated the connection between quilting and computational thinking through surveys, interviews, focus groups, and workshops. Based on our findings, we developed instructional workshops for adult quilters, which were held remotely due to the COVID-19 pandemic. We also developed online quilt design software that could be used by quilters during and after our workshops. 

The workshops and software were designed to encourage sharing skills and knowledge between the quilters. The quilt design software uses generative AI to suggest quilt designs while also letting the quilter customize their designs and easily share with others. Anyone using the software can see what other users are creating, and choose designs to remix and modify real-time. We also created workshop materials so that quilt guilds could explore the software and discuss computing concepts together.

As part of this project, we conducted a survey and focus group with adult quilters to ask about their experience and interest in learning about computer science. We found that: 1) quilters are typically open-minded about their ability to learn highly technical methods when it's related to quilting; 2) quilters are more inclined to learn computing when it's related to something fun or enriching, especially if it's likely to further their quilting skills; 3) quilters place value on the time invested in making a physical object; 4) quilters identify challenges with sexism, racism, and ageism in both quilting and computing.

Based on these findings, we identified three core design philosophies which we used when designing the Code Crafters software. 1) Promote social connection and sharing, which are common features to both quilting (e.g. quilting bees, quilt guilds) and computing (e.g. open source software communities). 2) Make the software relevant to quilters and familiar to even beginner quilters, by using familiar vocabulary and concepts from quilting -- common and simple patch types (half-square triangles, for example), and treating the design space as a design wall. 3) Introduce more abstract computational thinking concepts, rather than specific programming skills. By using the software and interacting with each other, participants learn about how the quilt generation algorithm works, as well as how data is organized.

Once the software was created, we were able to run multiple workshops with quilters. From the workshops we learned: 1) quilters find the software easy to pick-up and enjoyable to use; 2) quilters are motivated to share the software with others in their guild and social networks; 3) quilters use the software for inspiration, but do not feel compelled to make the designs into quilts, and 4) quilters can use the the Code Crafters software as a conversation starter and metaphor when discussing the social impacts of computers and generative AI.

Following both the COVID-19 pandemic and the explosion of interest in generative AI, the importance of building computational literacy among the general public is only growing. Yet, computer science education often focuses on children, college students, and young professionals. In our workshops, we saw intergenerational groups of adults, including seniors, having deep conversations about the role of computers in society, ownership and attribution for generative systems, and algorithmic bias. It is our hope that the Code Crafters project lays the foundation for future work in both building links between computer science and quilting, and in other efforts to generate public awareness of computational thinking via interest and affinity groups.
